description:
It is a race to get to the race!  Be the first player to complete all four auto maintenance tasks and get to the racetrack finish line to win.

2-4 players move around the outer portion of the game then to the inner track. If a player makes it to the center track without completing all tasks that player must continue to do laps around the inner track until the car mainenance is finished.

The first player to make it to the racetrack finish line and have completed all four maintenance jobs wins the game.

Contents:
1 Game board
4 pawns
1 die
24 game tiles (6 oil change, 6 paint job, 6 new set of tires, 6 tank of gas)

The fairies desperately want to return to their home among the stars. For this they need stardust (the lifeforce of fairies) and what better place to find it than in Starfall Forest?

Every now and then a star will come falling down into the forest where the fairies are hiding and waiting. As soon as a stars lands, the fairies are eager to get to it. Moving from tree to tree, as fairies prefer to stay hidden from sight, they all try to get to the star as quickly as possible. Only when a fairy has collected enough stardust can she make it back home to the stars.

So the race to the stars is on! But beware.. There are venomous snakes about. Try not to get bit as this will cost you the precious stardust you so desperately need to go back home.

All fairies will eventually manage to return home, clever as they are. But who will get there first?

Admiral of the Black is set in the Golden Age of Piracy. It is both a board game and a deck building game. Players take the roles of pirate captains and compete against each other by raiding merchant ships for trade goods and treasure that earn them Victory Points. They also must visit friendly ports to trade goods, add new crew members, and purchase arms and equipment. These new crew members, arms, and equipment cards are added to their decks.

The board is a map of the Caribbean with a hexagonal grid. Players move on the edges of the hexes while the merchant ships move from one hex to the next. A player may engage a ship in battle when its ship is on a hex edge adjacent to a merchant ship. Once an enemy ship is defeated in naval combat the player may initiate boarding combat.

Both naval and boarding combat are resolved through the player's Naval Combat and Boarding Combat decks. An additional six-sided die is added to the combat score.

The game ends when the Admiral of the Black (the leader of the pirates) is defeated and a new Admiral of the Black is declared by the player with the most Victory Points.

In 1982, Mexico's economy collapsed, and the government's response was to centralize the banks and devalue the peso. (This much, at least, is true...)

In the game world of Banditos, the Mexican people responded poorly to these changes, resulting in a decrease in effective security and an increase in creative accounting at the new Banco de Mexico. Once some of the "alternatively principled" people in the land of opportunity heard about this, they looked south of the border for their ventures.

You will play one of several American characters making runs into Mexico to pull bank heists. You will need to acquire vehicles, weapons, seed money, and maybe even some inside information to make it all happen.

The first player to get his character home with the equivalent of one million US dollars wins.

Players can acquire cards (vehicles etc.) by drawing them each turn, by buying them from other players, or by stealing them from the discard pile.

Doing anything deemed illegal, however, will bring "heat" to your character (if you steal from the discard pile or pull a heist,) or your vehicle (if you steal gas or pull a heist,) or Mexican cities (if you pull a heist.) 
It's up to you as a player to manage your risk and decide how desperate you are to acquire what you need versus how much heat you currently have.

If you have the guts to try a risky heist, it'll either pay off or you'll land in a Mexican jail and have to play catch-up.

A Rummy-like card game with World Literature as theme. Each card represents a famous book from the World Literature, including a (colored) theme, and a short description with highlighted keywords. Players try and lay combinations of cards based on the colored theme (beginners), the keywords in the description (intermediate), or self-defined connections between the books (advanced).

Designed by Dutch writer and journalist Pieter Steinz.

This east German game simulates the cosmonaut's training that supposedly boys were always dreaming about. 
The first half of the game is a snakes and ladders part: Players roll dice and move ahead the strenuous training path. On some fields, they are allowed to move ahead fast because of "excellent performances", other field lets them fall behind for "insufficient performances". When a player reaches the 30th field of the track, his or her plastic cosmonaut is inserted into a plastic rocket and is ready for take-off. After rolling a six, the rocket is moved along a path to a distant planet, and the game turns into a basic roll and move game. After skipping a turn on the planet, players take off again and reach earth again on a different path. The first player to return home safely is the winner.

The game is free of political agitation and focusses on the hardships of the cosmonaut's training. It is remarkable that this ancient game (which has only two pages of rules anyway) contains a rule overview on the back side of the rule booklet.

The box says "An Exciting 3 Dimensional Game." Aimed at children under eight years old.

It is a race to see who can get through their 'cheese tunnel' first. Luck and colour recognition are all part of the race.

The tiles are placed face down. Players draw a tile - If it matches their colour they can move their mouse along the tunnel. If it is not their colour, return it to the pack. There are penalties for drawing a cat card.

The first player to get their mouse to the end of the cheese tunnel, wins.

Contents
4 - 3D Cheese Tunnels
4 Mice Holes
4 Mice
24 Mice and Cat Tiles.
1 Cat Backcloth.
1 Set of Rules.

Typical of this game in the public domain, each player deploys one’s own fleet of five ships on a ten-by-ten square grid that is hidden from the opponent. Because each ship consists of a series of pegs that are the same color rather than physical ship, units may be placed on the grid diagonally as well orthogonally. In turn, each player shoots at the other's grid by calling a location. The defender responds by "Hit!" when the call happens to be the location of a unit or "Miss!" when a unit is not located there. Each player tries to deduce where the enemy ships are and sink them. First to do so wins. Players use an erasable crayon to record calls on a second smaller grid.

A shooting target game featuring famous images associated with the Outlaw of Sherwood Forest.

The target has four characters. Two mounted Normans and two unmounted knights. I think the mounted character in plain clothes so-to-speak is probably the dastardley Sheriff of Nottingham.

Each player takes turns and the one who has the most successes after a pre-agreed number of rounds, wins.

A twist on the mechanics used in Blow Football games but this time a lot more abstract and aimed at adults (judging by the image on the box).

This is probably an original Edwardian Parlour Game. The box is placed in the middle of the table with the cup fixed upon the post in the centre. Each player takes a blower (8 included), and placing the coloured balls one by one in the end of it, endeavours to blow them into the box. Each player in turn puffs all the balls, and scores the numbers of the divisions into which they fall. A ball resting in the Cup counts as 25.

The game is won by the player who first scores 50 or 100, as may be agreed when starting.

A simple game linked to all things Swiss.

Each player is given 12 counters, 2 of which are put into a pool. The throw of a die determines how far you move. When landing on a numbered square, the player refers to the list of places corresponding with the number and pays to or receives from the pool, the numbers of counters stated.
When landing on a mountain pass - You must pay 1 counter to all other players. Customs squares will cost you 3 Counters!

The player who first reaches or passes No. 132 Basle and takes the pool, and the winner is the one with most counters.

Contents
1 Playing Board.
4 Playing Pieces.
Large Amount of Counters.
1 Die.
1 Set of Rules.

Pirate Hunter is a push-your-luck dice and card game with opportunities for player interaction. Players compete to capture pirates by rolling dice against a challenge number shown on each pirate card. 
Players must manage their dice pool carefully while taking just enough risk to stay ahead of the others.

The more pirates a player captures, the more risk their dice will be lost to Davy Jones along with the plunder accumulated that round.

Some rolls give dice, some rolls send dice to Davy Jones! In a pinch, players may call for the aid of another player and then negotiate a settlement for the assistance. But be careful, those lending aid are also putting their dice at risk.

Will you keep your plunder in your hold and risk the roll with fewer dice or use it to buy back dice and risk not having enough plunder to win in the end?

The Game of WordHound is played by two to four players. The Object of the game is to make an answer belonging to the category in play from the letters on your letter rack.

During your turn you draw letters from the letter bag, one at a time, until you draw a letter you want to keep. When you keep a letter, your turn is over and you pass the bag to the player on your left. Letters you don't want are placed face up on the letter board where they may be taken by other players. Letters you keep are placed on your letter rack.

The first player to make an answer using all the letters on his or her rack wins the round. The winner scores two points for each letter in his or her answer, plus a bonus equal to the number of the round being played. Other players score one point for each letter in their partial answer if every letter on their rack is used in the partial answer. Players score zero points if there are any unused letters on their rack when the round ends.

An answer may consist of one or more words and may be singular or plural. Blank tiles may be used as any letter and are scored as a letter. Spaces between words and other punctuation are assumed and do not affect scoring.

The player with the highest score after six rounds of play wins the game.

Promotional game published by J S Fry & Sons, a leading manufacturer of chocolate at this time (most famous for the TV adverts for "Fry's Turkish Delight).

A basic roll and move game, taking ideas from Ludo in some places. Each player has four men and their designated start point. The board track covers various encounters with fairground attractions. When you land on one, you must follow the instructions. If you land on another player's piece, that piece is sent back to the start.

First to get all four pices home, wins.

The game was despatched as a flat-pack, so you had to provide your own playing pieces and dice.

Game for children to play on long car journeys. The board is magnetic, especially important because the game is intended to be played in a moving car.

Cards provide the things to spot and you can score from 1 to 6 points depending on the rarity of the thing to spot. As you score points, you move your player marker along the track. The one who is furthest up the track, wins.

One Night Only is a game for 3 to 5 players who each take the role of a Band in their humble beginnings and guide them to the heights of Fame. Players choose actions to increase of Band's confidence so they will be able to play larger and larger gigs - thus gathering more and more Fame (and Money). Next they will bid Cash to hire a Bookie who will use his prestige to get the Bands gigs. Players can even play gigs together as Headliner and Opener. At the end of the game, whoever has the highest Fame, is the Winner!

Very strange game and nothing to do with the more famous Boggle game.

Place the heads on a smooth surface and put an eye-ball in each socket, making sure that the pupils do not show. All players then place a fly disc on their cards in an agreed position, say, at the top of the head. Players then proceed to align the eyes on the fly by moving the card about In any direction or by rotating It. The first to achieve the alignment then decides where all players shall next place the fly. The eyes remain in the position achieved at the end of the first round. The player who is first 3 times is the winner.

Action game. Each player has three balls that must be loaded into a spring-like device, one at a time. If you press down on the device and then let go, the ball will fly out, hopefully towards the board. On the board are 9 squares, each square having a point value. Furthermore, each square has a fixed ring and the ball must stay within a ring to score. The scores range from 5 to 30 points.

First to reach a pre-agreed total score, wins.

Rare word game from around the turn of the 20th century. Devised at a "Famous London Literary Club", it was probably a new idea over 100 years ago.

52 cards all feature letters, each with a value that relates to the rarity of the letter in the English language (For example, an E would be 4, a Q would be 1, and so on). This value is important because if a player goes out whilst you still hold cards, then you give him the score of your unused cards - i.e. you are not penalised much for holding 'difficult' letters but you are if you hold common letters.

The game mechanic is simple. In a turn a player may lay as many cards as he wants but he must always have in mind a genuine word that could be spelt out eventually. For example, you might lay an L. The next player lays a T after the L (he is thinking of SALT). The next player might lay an I and an M after the T (he is thinking of ULTIMATE) and so on, until a player is challenged that there can be no such word with that array of letters (By the way, the letters must stay in the order they are laid, there is no rearranging letters). If challenged, a player must prove that he was thinking of a word, and if proven true, he receives payment (counters) from the others. If he was bluffing, he pays out counters to the persoin who challenged him.

When the game time is finished, the one with the most counters, wins.

By the way, in 1900 or so, they must have been aware of Analysis Paralysis because there is a fixed rule 'If you take longer than 30 seconds to play or pass, you forfeit your turn and must draw an extra card into your hand'.
And another oddity, how often are you told to enjoy your game - in Latin? The phrase Experientia Docet!, is used at the end of the rules

A mini game for 2 players by David Smith

Published in Plato magazine

Before You Start


     Draw a large circle and place 9 circular spaces at equal intervals around the circle.
     One player uses 4 small silver coins as pieces.
     The other player uses 4 small bronze coins. 


The Play


     Each player in turn places one of their pieces on the playing board until all but one of the nine spaces is occupied.
     Then each player at each turn must either
         move an own piece into an adjacent space in either direction or
         single jump one own piece over one adjacent enemy piece into an empty space immediately beyond the enemy piece (As in Chinese Checkers) or
         double jump one own piece over two enemy pieces one space apart with vacant spaces between and immediately beyond the two pieces jumper over. (Like a double jump in Chinese Checkers).
    
     Pieces jumped over are captured and removed from the board.
     Last player with a piece or pieces still in play wins the game.


Copyright 2007 David L. Smith, NZ

As with traditional bingo, the goal is to be first to fill in the game card so as to reproduce the pattern selected at the beginning of the game.

Game Cards have boxes to fill in. Though they are all different, the game cards present all of the same combinations. On a total of 25 boxes, you will find 9 différent combinations.

Progress of the game; To get the desired combined value, all players have the right to roll the dice up to 3 times each turn. All six dice must be used for the first roll, but for the 2nd and 3rd rolls, the player has the choice of the number of dice to be rolled.

Jesus Christ has promised us that he will be returning, and as a follower of Christ we know that this is true. But what about the people that don't know? Jesus gave us our great commission to go into all the corners of the world and share the gospel, and that is exactly what we will do. 

Your character cards will be your friends, your family and your fellow church members, each with their own set of unique skills and encouragements. When a coal is separate from the fire, it grows cold. Keep great people around you and your faith will grow.

You will also have support, in the form of churches, bible studies, small groups and even education. These support cards will stay in play and give you greater opportunities to travel and spread out across the world. But the mission field starts right at home, will you witness to your neighbor or to a total stranger?

You may travel across the entire globe on mission trips. Some may be only for a single turn (think of it as a youth group trip to the Ukraine or Mexico) and some may take over the rest of the game (such as settling a family in another country, or becoming a pastor for a military branch overseas). Wherever you go, you will always have people to witness to.

The win condition. Sharing Christ's love is not a race, and cannot be kept track of via face down prizes or a life total. So we create a new card type, the Mission card. Therefore go into all of the world, and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them and and teaching them to obey everything I have commanded you. Each player will have at least one Mission card within their deck, and when you have met your requirements listed on the mission card, you can reveal it to your opponent. The first player to finish their mission does not automatically win however, as the game is not a race. Instead, each Mission has an assigned point value based on its difficulty, and when one player runs out of cards in their deck, whoever has more Mission points wins that game.

Don't think for a moment that lower point values are easy and high point values are hard, remember the woman who gave two coins? Her gifts to the Father were greater than those of the rich men.

A bingo style game with two variants.  In the first ruleset, the caller calls out an amount, and the players check their cards which show pictures of coins for a match.  A row of four across, three down, four corners or entire card wins (winning pattern announced at the start of the game.

In the second ruleset, the game is the same but the cards and calling are different.  Players have a card with coin amounts instead of pictures of coins.  The caller calls out a description of a set of coins (i.e. "two dimes and one nickel").

AKA: Quizmo Money

Lexicons of Dueling is fast to learn, fast to play, and has hundreds of possible variations to the outcome of a battle! The cards are very easy to understand. The tactics are not just in the cards, it involves you learning your opponent’s style, the way they are thinking, and trying to figure out their next move! While they do the same to you! Each card has defense/attack/body positioning and weapon flow represented in such a way that you could even imagine the actions you are performing as you play.

Game Features:

     NOT a collectible card game. There are no perfect combos other than the ones your opponent didn't block. There are no super rare cards that will imbalance the game to those who can afford them. Every player has an equal chance to win, if they keep their wits about them, or get the opponent to lose theirs.
     Status cards that can increase your chance of victory, but not to the degree that a peasant cannot still best a king, if he plays his cards right. Anybody can win against anybody.
     Simple! Addition and subtraction rules; no tokens, no paper, no life counter, no phases, no arguing rules. The deck is all you need to play..... and an opponent. That will help a lot. You can practice with a single deck random solitaire if you want, but it is much more challenging with a thinking opponent.
     Tournament Play. They all have them, but not all of them will have the flavor of ours. You fight to gain status, from peasant, squire to knight, and so on. As you win you can fight well in higher status tournaments, and one day, maybe fight for the title of King! There are several characters that you can collect during the tournaments, and each of them can become royalty if you succeed!


As a fighter learns he gets better, as they win they gain status in the society they live in. Each status upgrade gives the player an extra skill to survive battles at higher ranks. They can always fight higher ranks than they are, but they can expect to have more of a challenge. They can fight lesser ranks, but they will receive a lesser reward for fighting below their station. The skills fit the rank: a Squire learns to move quickly so gains a dodge. A Knight learns the use of armor for a time, etc. Status cards represent goals and bragging rights you can prove you earned, and skills learned from battle.

This game includes the following expansions; 
- French Rapier
- Two handed Scottish Claymore
- (Introducing) Japanese Katana

Pitch It! - Who's Got the Million Dollar Idea? is a dynamic and social game requiring blissfully creative nonsense, but also a keen eye and sharp ear for what’s marketable. It is both fun and challenging! You are charged with the task of selling conventional products to unconventional clientele.

HOW TO PLAY
A combination of ‘What?’ card (product) and ‘Who?’ card (target audience) is picked. The goal for you (or your team) is to sell the ‘what’ to the ‘who’. For example, ‘potting soil’ needs to be sold to ‘police officers’, or ‘bath toys’ to ‘bankers’, or ‘sunscreen lotion’ to ‘NASCAR fans’…you get the idea. Summon your creative mojo to come up with a catchy idea for product title, slogan, and logo. Then pitch your best ideas to your friends. After that, sit back and listen to what others have done. Vote for the best idea presented – it may be yours, but nobody can vote for themselves. The winner of the most votes gets the $1 Million prize for that round. Play more rounds until someone reaches the ultimate goal of $5 Million.

The object of this game is to move your pawn along "love tracks" and reach the finish square. Rolling a die determines how far along the "love track" you may move on your turn. In so doing, you win time to kiss the person of the opposite sex closest to your pawn. When you land on a square with a heart sign, cupid sign, male sign, or female sign, you draw a card with the matching sign and follow the instructions. The first person to complete all of their card-driven tasks and reach their finish square first, wins the game.

From the game box: "Seven Minutes in Heaven is an entertaining game that will liven any party. The object is to strategically race along love tracks and reach the finish squares. You will find the journey sensuously exciting, intellectually stimulating, and emotionally thrilling. This game is a unique "ice breaker", because the fun experienced along the love track makes everyone a winner."

Promotional game made by Waddingtons for Blue Label Fyffes Brand of bananas. Fyffes were the most famous supplier of bananas in Britain, mainly thanks to a catchy TV advert featuring the slogan "Unzip a Banana".

Top Banana is based on the Banana Industry, its pitfally and its successes. You travel around the banana-shaped board, buying plantations and then shipping your produce to the marketplace in Britain.

Although it is a familiar type of game, suggested by Monopoly, income is dependent on that which you can raise by making and selling (there is no "Collect 200 when you pass go").

The richest player wins if 'time' is called or if that player is the only one still in business.

The goal is to be the first to succeed three humanitarian missions in 3 different countries.
The board represents two circuits: an external circuit to collect the necessities of the mission, and an internal loop to achieve the mission.

In each round, the player rolls the dice and advance in the direction he wants and if his pawn lands on a square of an element it needs to collect, it takes that element, otherwise it says "I give" and can assign this element against a Solidarity card to the player who needs it for his own mission.

First player to succeed his/her three missions is the winner and is named the best chef.

The game is a journey on a world map that indicates the important places in the production of Cocoa.

In his turn player roll the dice, move around the board and will be asked questions about Cocoa!

The first player to collect enough bean-cards for correct answers is the game.

The goal is to bring the most of cups of Nesquik at locations of its own pawns, in the area called "Safety Zone". Whoever has the most cups won.

Each player roll the dice in his turn and moves either his checkers or cups (yellow pins) on the ground the number shown on the die. 
It is forbidden to cross a pond, a hedge, a pawn or a cup or, to be with two checkers on the same box. A pawn of the opponent can be eliminated when you're passing with one of his own pieces.

You're exobilogist!
Space university of unknown life forms (SUULF) gave you task to find new, unique animals, plants and humanoids from outer space.

During game players collect cards (which reflect information about some species) from 4 decks (1deck=1planet) for making up encyclopedies, articles and guides or they just can deliver some exponates to museum of SUULF :)

During each turn players can do 1 action, which are:
Explore planet- (take a card from planet decks)
Write text- place 2 cards from your hand facedown
Publish text- get VP for text you've written
Give exponates to SUULF museum- discard cards which are not useful (for VP)

Game ends when there is no unrevealed cards in the planet decks.

The one who manages the best sets of cards will get more VP and become GREATEST EXOBIOLOGIST.

"An educational activity to teach and reinforce vocabulary skills" says the cover of the rulebook. There are four decks of cards, ranked by difficulty, that each contain three words, and their definitions. The basic game is for somebody to read all three words, and one of the definitions. The person or team whose turn it is has to identify which of the words goes with the definition read. A spinner decides what level of word (1 through 4) is used, and if the guess is correct, that team earns 100 to 400 points. First time to 5000 wins.

Welcome to the world of Zulu 6: the world's deadliest covert special missions force.

Assembled from the ranks of the most elite special forces units from around the world, the 6 warriors of Zulu Team are the guardians of humanity against the evil faction known as S.C.A.R. (Soldiers of Chaos, Anarchy & Rebellion).

Six of the world's top ten elite fighting forces are represented among the members of the Team: the Russian Spetsnaz, the French Naval Commandos, Israel's Shayetet 13, the U.S. Army Airborne Rangers, U.S. Marine Special Operations Command and the U.S. Navy SEALs.

Choose your side: one player controls Zulu 6 while the other controls S.C.A.R. The objects of the game: During each mission, Zulu 6 must use their elite combat skills to complete 2 mission objectives. S.C.A.R. must stop them with the use of overwhelming forces.

The game begins with the Zulu player choosing 3 of the 6 team members as his/her first assault team while S.C.A.R. player builds the game board by laying out 4 inch map tiles printed with a dirt path cutting through a jungle, placing each tile so that the path is continuous until the line of sight ends in a curve or a 3-way "T". As the Zulu 6 team moves along the path, the S.C.A.R. player continues to build it. Some of the map tiles contain hazards designed to slow the Zulu 6 team members while others contain mission objectives such as a prison camp, a weapons facility and a downed spy plane. There are also map tiles that contain symbols that allows the S.C.A.R. player to place a number of his troops in that tile to keep Zulu 6 from completing its mission. The S.C.A.R. player also has the ability to spawn more troops to keep the danger moving.

Combat between the 2 armies is resolved using 6-sided dice (D6). Each Zulu 6 team member has a stat card that explains his special skill and lists how many attack dice he gets during combat as well as areas to keep track of ammunition spent during combat (10 slots) and wounds taken (3 slots). Each time a Zulu 6 team member attacks, a marker is moved 1 space along his ammo track. The same happens when a team member takes a hit. Every roll of 5 or 6 on a Zulu 6 die roll is a kill. Each S.C.A.R. trooper only gets 1D6 and a roll of 6 on the die is a wound on the target Zulu 6 team member.

As the game progresses, Zulu 6 races to achieve mission objectives as S.C.A.R. sends wave after wave of troops at them. All the while, Zulu 6 receives 5 mission points for each objective achieved and for each S.C.A.R. troop killed and may use these points in trade for special actions such as healing a wound, an extra attack die, an ammo drop to reload weapons or even to call in reinforcements if a Zulu team member is lost in combat.

There are 3 missions to complete that make up the core game, each with 2 objectives.

With expansions coming soon featuring different mapped environments, daring missions, and new team members, you can take Zulu 6 around the world battling the evil forces of S.C.A.R.

It is a funny card party game about finding right words. Players trying to find words matching category shown by dice and containing two letters shown by cards. The game comes with two variants. In a more difficult one players also tries to collect letter cards and make sets of it to earn more points at the end of a game.

A strategic American football action game with hidden movable defenders and a fold-out stadium. Gameboard inserts are available for conversion to Basketball, Soccer, & Ice Hockey.

Before each play, the Defensive player (D) secretly sets his Linebackers -- 3 blue INDEPENDENTLY MOVABLE static-cling dots -- on a hinged, clear plastic, overlay.  He then swings the overlay against side of stadium and hides the Linebackers with a large black card.

The Offensive player then studies the tacklers printed on the field, HIDES HIS EYES WITH HIS PLAYBOOK, and either marks a line on the field with an erasable pen on a run, or lifts the pen and tries to land on a pass receiver (and then runs from there).  D tells him when he runs into a tackler, and then both players look at the field while D flips the overlay onto the field to see if a Linebacker tackled him sooner, caused a fumble, or batted down/intercepted a pass.

From the website:
"With an erasable pen and your EYES COVERED by a Playbook, how well can you evade tacklers, pass to receivers, or execute kicking plays?  That’s the challenge of Out of Sight Football! But beware your opponent’s hidden Linebackers! They can Stuff Runs, Intercept Passes, Cause Fumbles, or Blitz when you least expect it! Includes Kickoffs, Punts, Field Goals, Sacks, Safeties, Blocked Kicks, Fake Kicks, Laterals, Run Blocking, Injuries, Clock Management, Slo-Mo Replays, and a Playbook with fifteen offensive plays plus variations (left, right, middle) for OVER 40 total play choices."

A great way to learn American football.

Full sysselsättning ("Full employment") is a game about managing a borough / local council and how to handle the tax payer's money in order to best put them into use.

The game consists of a large plastic circular board on which the players get a 6th. The board is separated into squares on which the players can build. By doing so they manage differend aspects of a township, like a political administration in a small town. The game has a path around the edges on which the players move. Those spaces give them different opportunities and makes the players dra cards containing various events, much like the cards in Monopoly. One interesting thing in this game from 1975 is that the players mark their buildings on the plastic board using whiteboard markers. This must have been a rather early use of that in a boardgame.

Includes land development, unemployment issues, building of inustries, malls, water cleaning facilities, summer house areas and family homes. Four different variants of the rules provide different levels of difficulty. There is also squares for "?"-cards which is a variant where the players are meant to construct cards of there own to tweak the game.

HIRÞ (pronounced hirth) is a two-player abstract strategy game in which two leaders (Viking kings) fight over control of a piece of land. The first to either control the five middle spaces or push the other player's king off the board wins. Although it has a relatively small board (eleven squares), the ability to use moves to build stronger units makes the gameplay quite intricate. The game is designed in recent times but with the ambition of resembling a game that could potentially have been found in a Viking grave.

In the game, the players start on each short end of the board and take turns. Each turn they can make five moves. For a move, a player either moves one piece (Hird or King) one step, moves a Hird into or off a Karve (boat), or moves a Karve and all Hirds on it one step. A Karve may have at most four Hirds on it. Pieces entering empty spaces have to stop. Pieces entering enemy-controlled spaces stop on the line between the spaces. After a player's five moves, any conflicts (pieces on lines) are resolved. All pieces except empty Karve are worth 1. The King is tiebreaker. In case of a loss, solitary Hirds are removed from the game, Karves and Hirds in Karves are removed from play, and Kings have to retreat to an adjacent empty or friendly space. If there are no possible squares for the King to move to, the player loses. If after their turn a player controls all five middle spaces, that player wins.

There is also a doubling coin in the game affecting points received if several games are played. Normally a game is won after receiving five points.

English:

TOGETHER WE ARE STRONG!

A game about problems and their solutions for 2 - 4 players.

In our daily lives we are often faced with various problems, which may harm our contentedness and feelings of happiness. These problems may be of bodily, social and/or mental nature. To solve these issues, there are numerous solutions (or at least approaches) and helpful people covering all aspects – bodily, social and mental.

This easy to pick up, educational yet fun-to-play card game tries to recreate these aspects of our living reality in a more or less abstract manner. The game should be a cooperative experience, in which not one is declared winner and the others losers in the end. Not selfishness and only striving for one’s own benefit, but rather helping each other should pave the road to victory. All players win TOGETHER. Nobody should be left behind. Thus the name of the game!

In "Together we are strong!" players cooperate to solve their problems or problems of other players by playing "solution" cards which can be boosted by "helper" cards. At the beginning of his or her turn, the active player draws cards from a shared 60 card deck containing problems, solutions and helpers. For each problem a player solved on his or her own, he or she receives two smiley-chips (Victory Points). If players work together to solve a problem, each player involved gets one smiley-chip. When the draw deck is depleted, all players must have reached a minimum of smiley-chips / Victory Points (depending on the number of players) in order to win the game. If one or more players have not reached that goal, everyone loses.

Developed by a studied social worker, this game is ideal for social workers and other people working in the social sector as well as for people/families who have experience with psychosocial problems, while still providing a pleasant gaming experience for other interested gamers as well.

Français :

L’UNION FAIT LA FORCE !

Un jeu de problèmes et de solutions, pour 2 à 4 joueurs.

Nos vies quotidiennes regorgent de problèmes de toutes natures, psychologiques, relationnels ou physiques, de sorte qu’il n’est pas toujours facile de conserver notre équilibre et notre confiance en nous. Heureusement, nous pouvons recourir à des gens compétents et à des recettes éprouvées pour les surmonter.

Dans ce jeu facile d’accès, éducatif, mais qui n’oublie pas le plaisir, le but est de recréer ces aspects de la vie de façon quelque peu abstraite, et de les combattre tous ensemble, d’où le titre ! Il n’y aura ni vainqueur ni vaincu dans ce défi avant tout coopératif ; l’entraide, et non l’égoïsme, sera la clé de la victoire. Nul ne doit être laissé pour compte !

Les joueurs doivent utiliser et échanger des cartes de Solutions et de Soutiens pour résoudre leurs Soucis et ceux des autres. Chaque problème surmonté rapporte deux pions Sourire, que l’on partage si l’on s’est fait aider par un autre. À la fin de la pioche, chacun doit avoir gagné un minimum de Sourires qui dépend du nombre de joueurs, sinon tout le monde est perdant.

Développé par un professionnel du secteur social, ce jeu sera idéal pour vos collègues, votre famille, ainsi que pour quiconque connaît, ou a connu, des expériences difficiles. Mais tout le monde peut aussi y jouer rien que pour le plaisir.

Total Strategy is a 2 player strategy game.

Both players take control of an army of 32 units in the arena. The armies are made up of 12 different types of unit including infantry, cavalry, chariots and war elephants. Each unit has its own strengths and weaknesses so a careful balance of strategy is required to be a successful general.

The object of the game is to out maneuver your opponent and capture their general.

The game-play is historically realistic, players can use maneuvers from classic battles directly in the game to improve their chances of victory. This level of realism makes the game both easy to learn yet deceptively difficult to master.

Players take it in turns to move all their pieces, moving and attacking. Play then passes to their opponent. The winner of each attack is decided by the combat pot. The game finishes when one player captures the opponents general.

As with all Total Strategy Games the game is designed to be customisable by the players once they become proficient.

The best face wins the game!

In Funny Faces, players take turns drawing a card and making a face that matches the illustration on that card.  The other players then race to place their token on the tile on the gameboard that best matches the first player's expression.  The player who correctly guesses the match collects the card.  First player to collect three cards wins!

A travel-sized version of Monopoly, with all of the pieces of the standard game (including Chance and Community Chest cards), just smaller, unlike Monopoly: The Portable Property Trading Game, which has some game play differences, such as using three dice and a chart rather than Chance and Community Chest cards.

Gameplay

On his turn, a player rolls two dice and moves that number of spaces around the board. If the player lands on an as-yet-unowned property, he has the opportunity to buy it and add it to his portfolio or allow the bank to auction it to the highest bidder. If a player owns all the spaces within a color group, he may then build houses and hotels on these spaces, generating even more income from opponents who land there. If he lands on a property owned by another player, he must pay that player rent according to the value of the land and any buildings on it. There are other places on the board which can not be bought, but instead require the player to draw a card and perform the action on the card, pay taxes, collect income, or even go to jail.

Goal

The goal of the game is to be the last player remaining with any money.

A home version of the arcade game where you use flippers to send the ball to the opposite end of the pitch. This is a reduced size so that it can easily be played on a table.

Both players stand at opposite ends of the pitch. Put the ball in play and frantic flipping becomes the order of the day. Whoever scores the most goals, wins.

The Game of the Sixties is the game of questions, mimes, songs or drawings.

The box comes in the form of a jukebox: the outcome of the dice indicates the category with which we will play. Mostly, this is to answer questions, but sometimes you need to make small fun events. We can then find themselves dancing the twist, to mime or sketch a profile of a star.

6 violins, 4 violas, 3 cellos, 2 basses, 5 Wind Instruments, 5 Percussion cards, 4 Brass, and even a harp and a piano are gathering for a harmonious concert.

You draw a card and put in front of you. You replay if you draw an instrument of a family You already have. 
There are also 3 special cards in this game:
The conductor can take a card from another player. 
Phone and alarm clock are not good for the ears and You lose a card!

Try to collect similar families and take pleasure in having the full Philharmonic Orchestra to win the game.

Contents:

     31 large cards representing the instruments,
     3 special cards: conductor / alarm clock / mobile

Game description from the publisher:

In a galaxy far far away, there is a planetary system composed of a great big sun and nine minor planets, four of which have been developed as mercantile planets more or less under the control of politicians and guilds. On each of these planets are a merchant guild, a guild of smugglers, a bazaar and the galactic government, and players can take special actions on each of these planets.

In RYÅª, a game of negotiation, bluffing and cube-drafting, players each represent one of the other five planets in this star system, with each planet having a different type of humanoid – such as sharks, amazons and meka goblins – and its own unique influences. These planets are open to prospecting, and with the proper financing players will be able to dig the resources they need to build their own RYÅª, a mother ship composed of "Rare Metal", "Memory Stone", and "Amber Magic". Players will need to cooperate with one another to raise the necessary resources, but they must also work for themselves in order to maintain an advantage over other players. Once assembled, the RYÅª comes to life as a living spaceship, and its owner wins the game.

Probable update from game box on publisher website:

Several centuries ago, a celestial Leviathan cried on Titan, our planet. Its tears flooded our cities and our land. The people of the Dragons did their utmost to save as many of us as they could: Goblins, Shibuke, Reptilians, Sharks, and Amazons. The survivors of this deluge were brought to Dala, the highest mountain range of our celestial body, with its 9 majestic summits. Nine summits that soon became nine islands.

In Matchpoint, the first title in The Game Master's "Smart & Fun" game line, players take turns placing one of two tiles in hand onto the playing area, turning the tile this way and that to determine the best way to earn the most points.

More specifically, each tile is comprised of four colored quadrants, with each quadrant having a number of pips: purple has five pips, blue has four, and so on. One tile is placed face-up on the table at the start of the game. On a turn, you place a tile next to tiles already in play, then score the sum of all pips in the colored areas that you add to with the placed tile. (In the advanced version of the game, you multiply the sum of all pips by the number of colors that you matched on that turn.) You then draw a replacement tile, and the next player takes her turn. whoever has the most points when the tiles run out wins!

The rules also include a solo variant.

"Princesses and Knights" in English
Card game on the evolutionary theme of princesses and knights. By assembling the cards by 4, we can reconstruct various skits. The cards are laid on the table. Whoever gets the first card of a sketch can begin. The player may now find next card of this sketch etc. and finish the 4-cards sketch first to win the game.
Contents: 32 cards for eight sketches of four maps (castle courtyard of the castle, tower, dining room - the illustrations are duplicated, once with the characters, once without character), rules.

Similar with Memory

All photos are by Francois Koch. They represent different animals. Children must not find images that look alike, but those that show the same animal.

The race is on! Can you beat the Ogre to the treasure? It's your job to make a path from START to the treasure and collect the three keys that will open the treasure's locks before the Ogre gets there. Strategize, cooperate, and build the path together.

Children as young as two can play this co-operative tile laying game.  On their turn, the player draws one tile from the bag, and it will either show a piece of path or picture of the Ogre.

Working together the players need to first make a path to the three keys that open the treasure and then lay a path to the treasure itself.  All the while, each Ogre tile gets him closer to the treasure, and the players losing.

Everyone works together on the tile placement and either they win together or lose together.

The game has simple rules and does not require reading, meaning that even kids as young as 2 can be involved.

As Marshal of the interstellar fleet, it is your duty to oversee the colonization of nearby regions of the galaxy and thereby ensure the perpetuation of your people at any cost. But your race is not alone in its aspirations for dominance of the cosmos, or in having the power to realize that goal. Races hailing from various star systems venture out in all directions. Many paths are dead ends, but some sectors have sizable deposits of rare minerals that can be refined into the precious fuel crystals that drive your space fleets onward. Soon, a trail of colonies leads out from your homeworld, and soon the races venture into the same cosmic regions. Don’t get too attached to your fleets or interstellar empire, because tides can and will turn quickly. Only you can determine the fate of your people: interstellar conquest or infinite servitude.

StelCon: Infinity is a light strategy war game on a galactic scale. 2-6 players can expect around 30-45 minutes per player, so 2 players can often power through a game in about an hour. The 6 player game is kept short by combining into 3 teams of 2 where the teammates execute their turns simultaneously.

Variable game board. There are 6 races to choose from, each with its own strengths. Although the jump lanes that connect the sectors forming the galactic map are printed on the game boards, each sector location is covered by a different card from the sector deck each game.

Sectors are drawn from the deck and placed as the players explore the galaxy, so you never know what you're going to get...unless you do some scouting with your fighter squads or happen to have some telepaths on board your ship (telepaths are handy that way). Some of the sector cards are identical and therefore also create a "bridge" which is a unique adjacency in addition to the normal jump lanes. All this makes for a very different board every time.

Moving your space fleet around is straight forward. Each ship can move 1 sector per turn, plus 1 extra sector per turn per engine MOD. Your space ships are modular in design, both from a gameplay and a literal perspective. You physically insert engines, extra guns, and fighter squads into holes in the space ships. We call these MODs.

Combat is simple but tense. Add up your firepower present at the battle site and then toss in a d6 roll. The opponent does the same. Compare the two totals, and the winner keeps the sector in question while the loser retreats and loses a ship from his fleet.

While the game is a conquest type game, it ends immediately when one player conquers any homeworld, so there's no eliminated player stuck waiting around for the game to finish.

Conquest cards are the soul of the game. The deck of 120 cards gives tons of gotcha moments, and serious replay value. They allow you to do all sorts of fun things:


     Modify the firepower of your sector or your ship
     Boost fuel crystal production (the economy of the game)
     Steal or stop opponent's cards
     Cheat the dice
     Wipe out a whole sector
     Even influence battles your forces are not involved in, adding an element of table-talking diplomacy to the game
